p: On a global scale, diverse peoples and communities have been facing numerous pressures arising from the development geopolitics, as illustrated by the Covid-19 pandemic reality. As a strategy of resistance and (re)existence, many counter-hegemonic production and social organizations are being built within the pluriverse, which is understood as a wide range of social and environmental transformative possibilities, involving a pluralism of concepts, cosmovisions, and practices in tune with the principles of social and ecological justice. Pluriversal community-led alternatives are engaged in the construction of “a world where other worlds fit,” according to Zapatista’s principles, in contrast to the ethnocentrism and universalism propagated by Western and modern worldviews (Illich 1973; Escobar 1995, 2018; De la Cadena and Blaser 2018; Kothari et al. 2019).
